Message.Title: iPhone 5 outperforms Samsung's Galaxy S III in display test -Im in shock no can't be samsung is so advance company how can this happen?
Message.Msg: Monday, September 24, 2012, 20:49 pm iPhone 5 outperforms Samsung's Galaxy S III in display test By Mikey Campbell A comprehensive side-by-side examination of the Apple and Samsung flagship smartphones was performed by display testing firm DisplayMate Technologies, which found the iPhone 5's 4-inch Retina display to be more refined than the OLED unit found in the Galaxy S III. DisplayMate's "Flagship Smartphone Display Technology Shoot-Out" not only pitted the iPhone 5 against the Galaxy S III, but added in the iPhone 4's Retina display to show how Apple's display technology has advanced over the past two years. The test consisted of numerous tests covering screen reflections, brightness and contrast, colors and intensities, viewing angles, display power consumption and effect on battery life. "Apple has uncharacteristically understated how much better the display is on the iPhone 5 – something that could be an important factor for those considering whether to upgrade," said DisplayMate's Dr. Raymond Soneira. "In every category that we measure (except Brightness Decrease with Viewing Angle), the performance of the iPhone 5 display has improved over the iPhone 4, sometimes by a bit and sometimes by a lot." Compared to the iPhone 4, the iPhone 5 has decreased screen reflectance by 52 percent, boosted contrast by 57 percent and improved color accuracy. Soneira notes the iPhone 5's display calibration is very good and, while suffering from minor gamma intensity, that "It is still probably more accurate than any display you own, unless you have a new iPad. […] it is the Brightest Smartphone we have tested in the Shoot-Out series, it has one of the lowest screen Reflectance values we have ever measured, it has the highest Contrast Rating for High Ambient Light for any Mobile device we have ever tested, and it’s Color Gamut and Factory Calibration are second only to the new iPad. What are the downsides? The White Point is still somewhat too blue like most Smartphones, and at Maximum Brightness it has a shorter Running Time than the iPhone 4, which is not surprising since it has a larger screen and a larger Color Gamut but roughly the same capacity battery. As for Samsung's Galaxy S III, the device's PenTile display performed admirably, but the OLED technology the screen leverages is still being perfected and is not up to par with the LCD tech used in the iPhone 5. Highlights from the Galaxy S III test: The Brightness is about half of the iPhone 5 due to power limits from the lower power efficiency of OLEDs and concerns regarding premature OLED aging. The Color Gamut is not only much larger than the Standard Color Gamut, which leads to distorted and exaggerated colors, but the Color Gamut is quite lopsided, with Green being a lot more saturated than Red or Blue, which adds a Green color caste to many images. Samsung has not bothered to correct or calibrate their display colors to bring them into closer agreement with the Standard sRGB / Rec.709 Color Gamut, so many images appear over saturated and gaudy. Running Time on battery is less than the iPhone 5 due to the lower power efficiency of OLEDs, even given that the Galaxy S III has a much larger battery capacity and much lower Brightness. Overall, the iPhone 5 scored an "A" rating while the Galaxy S III earned a "B+" on poor calibration and viewing angle issues.

Message.Title: AuthenTec to reportedly ditch non-Apple customers in 2013 the samsungs of the world are in panic
Message.Msg: Monday, September 24, 2012, 18:46 pm AuthenTec to reportedly ditch non-Apple customers in 2013 By Mikey Campbell Fingerprint sensor maker AuthenTec on Monday reportedly notified existing customers that it will not be offering its security technology to the companies starting next year, causing a "state of panic" as the firms scramble to find comparable replacements. In an email to its customers, which includes Samsung, HP, Dell, Lenovo and Fujitsu, Apple acquisition AuthenTec reportedly said it will no longer be honoring orders come 2013, a source told Korean language website etnews. The announcement may be an indication of what Apple plans to do with the company and its technology after purchasing the firm in July for $356 million. AuthenTec is well known for its work in fingerprint sensor tech and it was rumored that Apple might be looking to implement the biometric security asset into an upcoming iPhone. A filing with the U.S. Security and Exchange Commission in August hinted at an advanced piece of hardware dubbed the "Smart Sensor" was key to Apple's acquisition. The sophisticated component goes further than simple fingerprint scanning by acting as a full-fledged touch pad controller, allowing UI navigation with one finger. The sensor is also capable of identifying different fingers which can be associated with certain tasks, like opening the phone app with a thumb or sending an email with a forefinger. One of the first companies to use the specialized part was Fujitsu with its Regza smartphone. AuthenTec's Smart Sensor technology. | Source: AuthenTec Before the iPhone 5 debuted on Sept. 12, rampant speculation pointed to inclusion of AuthenTec's sensors as part of a possible augmentation of Apple's Passbook app, which stores digital coupons, tickets and gift cards. The rumors turned out to be just that, however, as no biometric devices were found in the unit's teardown. While it remains unclear what Apple plans to do with AuthenTec's IP, for now the Cupertino company seems content in leveraging its new purchase to disrupt rival manufacturers' plans for fingerprint-based security.

Message.Title: AAPL co-founder Wozniak Applied for Aussie Citizenship
Message.Msg: Apple Inc. (AAPL) co-founder Steve Wozniak wants to become an Australian citizen and lists the government’s planned national broadband network as one of the factors behind his decision, the Australian Financial Review reported. Wozniak told a local radio station in Brisbane that he was “underway to become an Australian citizen,” according to the report. “It turns out I can keep my American citizenship,” he told Brisbane’s 4BC breakfast radio, the newspaper said. “I intend to call myself an Australian and feel an Australian, and study the history and become as much of a real citizen here as I can.”

Message.Title: NO GOOG MAP FOR iPhone
Message.Msg: TOKYO (Reuters) - Google Inc has made no move to provide Google Maps for the iPhone 5 after Apple Inc dropped the application in favor of a home-grown but controversial alternative, Google's Executive Chairman Eric Schmidt said. Apple launched its own mapping service earlier this month when it began providing the highly anticipated update to its mobile software platform iOS 6 and started selling the iPhone 5. But users have complained that Apple's new map service, based on Dutch navigation equipment and digital map maker TomTom NV's data, contains glaring geographical errors and lacks features that made Google Maps so popular. "We think it would have been better if they had kept ours. But what do I know?" Schmidt told a small group of reporters in Tokyo. "What were we going to do, force them not to change their mind? It's their call." Schmidt said Google and Apple were in constant communication "at all kinds of levels." But he said any decision on whether Google Maps would be accepted as an application in the Apple App Store would have to be made by Apple. Apple will have to go with the Best mapping...NOK map but it's more expensive....just like the iPhone5

Message.Title: New Apple Store in Hong Kong
Message.Msg: Lost in the shuffle of news was the announcement that Apple will open a 2nd Hong Kong store this Saturday (Sept. 29). This store will be located at the Festival Walk shopping mall. The significance of this Festival Walk store is: 1. The Festival Walk shopping mall is the first top quality shopping mall that Chinese tourists taking the train from Shenzen, China to Hong Kong come across. 2. This mall is located on top of arguably the busiest underground (subway) station in Hong Kong, where Chinese tourists can get off of the train from China and get onto the Hong Kong underground (subway) network. 3. Tourists from China continue to flood into Hong Kong to buy products that aren't fakes. Until the iPhone5 is released in China at the end of the year, this new Hong Kong store makes it even easier for Apple customers from China to buy the new iPhone and any other Apple products they want while visiting Hong Kong. The original Apple store in Hong Kong is located in a mall that's a bit more difficult to get to. There's no high-end shopping mall that's easier to reach for mainland Chinese visitors to Hong Kong than the Festival Walk shopping mall. Period. Very wise move Apple.

Message.Title: Why Didn’t Apple Sell More iPhone 5s Opening Weekend? How Do We Know It Didn’t?
Message.Msg: Why Didn’t Apple Sell More iPhone 5s Opening Weekend? How Do We Know It Didn’t? September 25, 2012 at 4:18 am PT inShare.SharePrint Apple sold a record five million iPhone 5s during the device’s first three days of retail availability. But it sold out its initial supply during the same time, leaving Wall Street with the impression that it could have sold significantly more and searching for explanations for why it didn’t. Among analysts that follow Apple, there are a few theories emerging on the company’s … imaginary iPhone sales shortfall. •This particular iPhone upgrade cycle might be larger than expected. Some analysts are reporting that a significant percentage of iPhone 5 buyers are consumers upgrading from the iPhone 4S. According to some recent Apple Store exit surveys — one from Topeka Capital Markets, for example — as many as 35 percent of respondents buying the iPhone 5 were upgrading from the iPhone 4S. In other words, people who aren’t yet eligible to buy the iPhone 5 at a subsidized price are spending hundreds of dollars more to upgrade to it anyway. And while that obviously doesn’t explain why Apple sold five million iPhone 5s instead of the six million to eight million some exuberant analysts had forecast, it might help explain why preorders sold out so quickly. •A number of analysts believe sales might have been significantly higher were it not for component supply constraints. Specifically, they say that supplies of the new in-cell displays that allow Apple to make the iPhone 5 so much thinner than its predecessor aren’t yet high enough to meet the level of demand Apple’s seeing. “We believe the key issue in today’s shipment data is in-cell supply constraints,” Barclays analyst Ben Reitzes said in a note to clients. “[Monday's] announcement fits with our view that Apple would only be able to ship limited quantities in the September quarter; we expect a solid production ramp and improved availability in C4Q12. … Estimates for iPhone 5 display supply are for only about 10 million screens for C3Q12, with a significant ramp to start C4Q12.” •Initial iPhone 5 supplies may simply have been constrained by the length of the one-month-plus manufacturing window Apple has typically allocated for iPhone launches. In other words, it has maxed out capacity and can’t raise it without adding still more production lines. •My own theory: The aggressive worldwide roll-out Apple has mapped out for the iPhone 5 is perhaps too aggressive and forced the company to cap sales in first-wave market in order to retain supply enough for the 22 additional markets getting the device this week. So Apple looked at its inventory, decided five million iPhone 5s was enough for a first weekend sales boast, and reserved the remainder for the second-wave launches scheduled for this Friday. •Finally, it could be that analyst expectations were simply too high and not at all grounded in reality. But in the end all of these theories are moot. Because ultimately we don’t know how many iPhone 5s were ordered over opening weekend. All we know is that Apple delivered at least five million of them to customers. For all we know there could have been twice that number in pending orders by the end of the weekend that Apple can’t deliver for another few weeks.

Message.Title: 22% android users are going to AAPl
Message.Msg: FORTUNE: The fact-packed pie chart above is part of a larger infographic posted last week by Ask Your Target Market, a roll-your-own market research start-up. This one was created by co-founder Lev Mazin and was based on an online survey of 600 smartphone owners completed Sept. 17. I'm not familiar with the firm and can't vouch for the quality of their target audience, although to Mazin's credit he published his questionnaire and a summary of his raw data here -- something you don't get from, say, Nielsen. The full infographic -- available as a PDF here -- has lots more info about the stated intentions of U.S. adults who plan to buy a smartphone in the next six months. Among the highlights: •73% already own a smartphone (and, naturally, 27% don't) •40% of smartphone owners have Google (GOOG) Android phones •22% of Android owners are planning to switch to an Apple (AAPL) iPhone (73% are sticking with Android) •23% of smartphone owners who plan to buy a new one already have an iPhone •9% of them are planning to switch to Android (83% are sticking with Apple)

However, anyone who travels, electronic maps are essential navigating large cities, trips, etc. If you were a realtor driving a prospect to show homes in areas you did not know, you sure would not look very professional when you could not find a home due to an unreliable mapping program. If mapping was not something the public wanted, it would not be in the product. Try driving around Houston, Texas without a map.

Topic.Title: Today's Lesson? Tim Cook is 5 Million Times Smarter than Gene Munster

Message.Msg: 31 countries in eight days is a very big launch schedule and I agree 10 million+ is more than doable - at least from a demand standpoint. Remember, Apple only books a sale on delivery - not orders nor shipping - so there will likely be some spillover into next Q from the outrageous demand across all geographies. I don't have a "price target" on AAPL. I'm really more focused on the fundamentals and I believe the "i" franchise as it stands right now is still gaining global traction. When you add in the $$$ potential for a blockbuster "mini" pad, a deal with China Mobile, and possibly a TV product next year, I just cant see how this stock won't make new all time highs over the next several Q's. The trick, as always, is to filter out the noise - including the absolute garbage spewed right here on a daily basis. And I will be adding to my position if we retrace to the $660 area (50 day moving avg) where buyers will enter in size, IMO. GL!

Message.Title: White Topeka : make no mistake that was an epic launch 4 reason why?
Message.Msg: read fools before sell Four reasons Apple's iPhone 5 sales were anything but soft By Philip Elmer-DeWittSeptember 25, 2012: 8:27 AM ET "Don't be fooled," writes an analyst. "This is an epic launch." FORTUNE -- Topeka Capital's Brian White, whose $1,111 price target for Apple (AAPL) is the highest we've seen from a mainstream analyst, issued a note Tuesday offering four reasons the market (which at one point Monday had knocked $16 billion off Apple's market cap) misread the significance of the 5 million iPhones sold last weekend. •"iPhone 5 Pre-Orders Were a Blowout and Double the iPhone 4S." This equates to 100% year over year growth for the iPhone 5 compared with 67% for the iPhone 4S. Pre-orders are demand-related, White notes, and not affected by short supplies. •"The iPhone 5 Pre-Orders Sell Out in an Hour Vs. Nearly a Day for 4S." The iPhone 4S took nearly a full day for pre-orders to sell out (i.e., ship within one week) versus about an hour for the iPhone 5. •"iPhone 5 Reaches 3-4 Weeks After Pre-Order Tally Vs. 1-2 Weeks for 4S." The shipping time for the iPhone 5 remained at 3-4 weeks Monday night and another 22 countries are set to launch on Friday. •"Most Apple Stores Sold Out of the iPhone 5 but Most Did Not for the 4S." White's survey found the iPhone 5 was sold out at approximately half of the U.S. Apple retail stores by Saturday (the second day) and 80-85% by Sunday evening (the third day). Did you catch that? More than eight out of ten of U.S. Apple Stores were out of stock by Sunday night. "Don't Be Fooled by 3-Day iPhone 5 Tally, " reads the headline of White's note. "This is an Epic Launch."

Message.Title: Apple Target Raised To $760 By Sell-Side Firm Pacific Crest Securities
Message.Msg: Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL)’s new iPhone 5, loved one day, and hated the next. iPhone 5 fevers invades the tech and financial world, and then riots break out at Foxconn. However, while this cycle plays, Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL) continues bringing in more and more cash each day. Additionally, Apple is getting some upgrades, which is helping to boost the stock price higher. The company’s stock price is hitting record highs on an almost daily basis. Pacific Crest Securities is the latest to join the upgrade bandwagon. The sell-side firm has increased its price target for Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL) from $690 to $760. The reason for the upgrade? Improved supply, very strong demand prompt higher iPhone estimates. Evidence of solid iPhone 5 supply and incredibly strong demand drive their FQ4 iPhone unit estimate to 28 million from 24 million and their F2013 iPhone unit estimate to 176 million from 163 million. An increase to iPhone unit and gross margin estimates offsets a decrease to their Mac unit and iPad gross margin estimates and drives their F2013 EPS estimate to $60.79 from $55.09. The anticipation of a larger iPhone user base in F2014 and, therefore, higher replacement sales, drives their F2014 iPhone unit estimate to 183 million from 169 million and their F2014 EPS estimate to $63.29 from $57.47. Some further notes from Pacific Crest summarized below: Increased iPhone estimates drive F2013 EPS to $60.79 from $55.09; F2014 to $63.29 from $57.47. They are raising their iPhone unit and gross margin estimates, which offset reduced Mac and iPad gross margin estimates. Their channel checks suggest that Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL)’s iPhone 5 component supply has been improving over the last couple of months, and they now believe that supply will support Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL) unit sales that are well ahead of their previous estimates. Additionally, early demand has lived up to their high expectations and appears sustainable through at least the March quarter. Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL) reported on Monday morning that the company sold 5 million units of the iPhone 5 in the three days following the phone’s release to retail. Pacific Crest believes that this suggests that the company could ship as many as 8 million iPhone 5s in the September quarter, above their original expectation of 5 million to 7 million. In total, this prompts an increase to their FQ4 (September), F2013 and F2014 iPhone unit estimates. In addition to the increase to their iPhone unit estimates, in their model they are slightly reducing their Mac unit estimates to account for weak global PC demand. They are also slightly lowering their FQ4 iPad unit estimate. However, Pacific’s F2013 and F2014 iPad estimates are unchanged and remain meaningfully dependent on a strong response to the iPad Mini, which they expect to launch in October. Higher estimates drive price target to $760 from $690. their $760 price target is based on 12.5x the analysts’ F2013 EPS estimate of $60.79. They even expect Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL)’s P/E multiple to contract toward their target multiple as the pace of growth likely decelerates. Significant new products or services are likely necessary to drive meaningful upside to their new price target. Market saturation will dramatically slow growth for the iPhone and iPad beyond F2013. They believe this limits room for upside beyond their $760 price target unless Apple launches a new and massively profitable product or service.

Significant new products or services are likely necessary to drive meaningful upside to their new price target. Market saturation will dramatically slow growth for the iPhone and iPad beyond F2013. They believe this limits room for upside beyond their $760 price target unless Apple launches a new and massively profitable product or service.

Message.Title: How this will work- part 8
Message.Msg: I'm not sure how many times i have written a similar post, but it has to be about 8 times, so we will go with that. 1. People will make a big deal about something minor. This always happens. Apple will fix it, and people will still act like its a big deal, and predict their downfall. 2. The stock price will drop for various reasons, all of which are lame, because the fundamentals are ridiculously good. Apple has amazing EPS growth, and has for years now, yet sales at PE=14-17. It gets no premium for its strength or success. 3. People who buy and hold like I do will make a ton of money. I have been in since 2008 and never sold a share. My last buys were in the mid 300's, and I still have 140% gains. 4. After a brief drop due to unrealistic concerns the stock will take off again when people finally wake up to the fact that apple is amazingly undervalued (Yet it still will not even get close to its true value). When EPS hits $50+ per shr and people realize that even at a PE of 15 the stock should be at least $750. Of course full year 2013 EPS will well above $50/shr, probably approaching $60. But let's say its only $55 (which would be the lowest EPS increase in years). That would put the stock price at a minimum of $825. 5. So people can come up with all kinds of messed up reasons why Apple is too highly priced, but as always those of us who have brains will come away making tons of money. Brief movements downward really mean nothing. I have been through too many of them to remember, only to see the stock take off in a huge way once people can't ignore the fact that Apple is dominating the market and making tons of money.

Message.Title: Apple: Jefferies Ups Ests; Upbeat On iPhone Screen Supplies
Message.Msg: Apple: Jefferies Ups Ests; Upbeat On iPhone Screen Supplies Peter Misek doesn’t see no stinkin’ parts shortages. The Jefferies analyst late yesterday upped his EPS estimates for Apple, asserting that the company is likely to sell 8-10 million iPhone 5 units in the September quarter. He now sees total unit sales for the quarter of 26 million, up from 23 million. (Though he trims his forecast for the December quarter to 55 million units from 58 million.) He also adjusted his model to add in a December quarter launch for the widely expected iPad mini, noting also that he now sees an Apple television launch in the March quarter. More interesting is Misek’s assertion that his checks find the addition of Sony to the list of suppliers – others include Sharp, LG and Toshiba – for the in-cell displays used in the iPhone 5. He says adding Sony to the mix “has alleviated what was the main bottleneck” in production of the phone. Misek thinks that solving the screen issue should “offset bear concerns” about disappointing sales of the phone in the opening weekend. Misek had been projecting sales of 8 million phones in the opening weekend; Apple said it sold 5 million. He thinks one issue is that Apple held back 2-3 million units for the launch of of the phone in additional countries this Friday. Meanwhile, the analyst sees a vast pool of potential buyers. In particular, Misek asserts that 170 million global smartphone subs will be coming off contract in the 2012 second half, with another 450 million coming off contract in 2013. He adds that the totals include 30 million iPhones coming off contract in the second half, and another 85 million next year. On the iPad Mini, he sees a late October launch, with 8 million Minis selling in the December quarter, and an ASP of $317, though he trims his expectations for older iPads by 3 million to reflect some cannibalization. Overall, he now sees December quarter iPad units of 26 million, up from 20.7 million. For the September quarter, he now sees revenue of $36.4 billion and profits of $8.91 a share, up from $34 billion and $8.05; consensus is $36.1 billion and $8.90. For the December quarter, he now projects $62 billion and $18.47 a share, up from $60 bilion and $17.44, and well ahead of the Street at $55 billion and $15.53. For the September 2013 fiscal year, Misek now sees $223 billion and $63.05 a share, way above consensus at $193 billion and $53.03. AAPL today is down 88 cents, or 0.1%, to $689.91.

Message.Title: AAPL is already outselling Nokia Lumias.
Message.Msg: All of Apple's (AAPL) detractors let out a loud, collective cheer that was heard all the way around the world when the company reported sales results for its new iPhone 5 smartphone device that missed consensus expectations. While we did not publish an estimate for Apple's iPhone 5 sales, we were content with the over five Million iPhone 5 devices sold by Apple during the opening weekend from Friday September 21st to Sunday September 23rd. We believe that investors need to approach Apple with the cool, calm, dispassionate, fair and balanced perspective that we take professional pride in with regards to our research. And on that note, we can see that although the Apple iPhone 5 only sold over five million for the opening weekend in 2012, it still exceeded the 4 million devices sold for the iPhone 4S 2011 in 2011 and the 1.7 million for the iPhone 4 in 2010. We can see that Nokia's (NOK) Lumia's sales volumes are lagging the iPhone because the Lumia only sold 1M devices in the second half of Q4 2011, 2M devices in the first quarter of and 4M in the second quarter of CY 2012, even though the Lumia had the benefit of Big Daddy AT&T (T) spending $150M to push the Lumia 900 to its customers. That means that Nokia has averaged 3 million Lumias over a 90 day period and that is pathetic when we compare it to the 5 million iPhones sold from September 21 to September 23.

Topic.Title: Apple will sell just enough to make the quarter

Message.Msg: Bingo. Well said. This isn' t hard to figure out ... unless you'r one of the mindless bashers on here. Apple wants to sell a pre-determined amount of iPhone 5's to *supplement* this quarter. By all accounts, that number is 8-10 million iPhone 5's. They are limiting supply, as to just hit whatever earnings number it is that they are okay with for the September quarter. After that, mark my words, there will be PLENTY of supply for the holiday quarter. Production began back in late-July. August + September, assuming their 2011 production capabilities of 350,000 phones per day, = 21 million iPhone 5's ALREADY assembled. And that's the low end number, as production may have begun as early the beginning of July. A second plant has now opened and their capacity is about 500,000 phones assembled per day. Whatever the case, Apple is being Apple, folks. The holiday quarter will be one for the record books. We're looking at a $22-$26 quarter. Virtually every line has been updated and the stores will be packed. iPhone 5 and the iPad Mini will be 1 and 2, as far as the holiday's most sought after gift goes. And whether they want to admit it or not, deep down, even the bashers know this.

Message.Title: Merrill Lynch/BOA Raised Target
Message.Msg: BofAML 12 Month Objective raised to $850.00 from $770.00 Equity | United States | IT Hardware 24 September 2012 Report: Apple - Positive view on iPhone 5 cycle intact; Maintain Buy "Positive view on iPhone 5 cycle intact; Maintain Buy Apple shares are underperforming today (down 1%+ vs. the S&P 500’s -0.3%), as the 5mn+ iPhone 5 units sold over the past weekend were below the Street’s heightened expectations. We believe most were expecting 6-10mn units over the first weekend, which, in our view, at the high end, did not fully take into consideration the limited initial supply. We believe overall demand remains strong and our estimates reflect most of these supply constraints, leading us to maintain our Buy rating and our above-consensus estimates. Maintain our iPhone 5 unit forecast of ~10/40mn in C3Q/4Q 5mn+ iPhone 5 units were sold since 9/21 in the US, Australia, Canada, France, Germany, Hong Kong, Japan, Singapore and the UK, vs. 4mn for the iPhone 4S last year. The company noted demand exceeding supply, with many preorders scheduled to be shipped in October. We continue to model 10/40mn iPhone 5 units in C3Q/4Q (total phones of 24/50mn), driven by (1) pre-order deliveries trickling through the quarter-end, with many pre-order customers in the US indicating earlier-than-expected shipment notification; (2) the 2nd phase of the global rollout on 9/28; and (3) continued strong demand for the iPhone 5 and improving in-cell production yield expected in C4Q. We estimate every 1mn of iPhone unit sales equates to $0.15 of incremental EPS. iPhone 5 international ramp accelerated vs. iPhone 4S The iPhone 5 is expected to launch in 22 more countries (including Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Italy, Spain and others) on 9/28 (a week after the initial release in 9 countries) and will be in over 100 countries by the end of the year. This is a more accelerated rollout than the iPhone 4S last year, which was available for preorder in 7 countries on 10/7/2011, released in 22 more countries 3 weeks later, on 10/28, and available in 70+ countries by the end of 2011."

Message.Title: Reality about iPhone 5
Message.Msg: Got my iPhone 5 on Sunday. There were no lines and no mass hysteria like the media would like us to believe. It's an OK phone, but hardly revolutionary and it's really not a meaningful pugrade over the 4/4s. I got one because I have a 4 year old iPhone 3G that barely works anymore. iPhone 5 is by no means a "must have" and it seems to me that's how most people feel about it. Despite all the hype, iPhone 5 will be nothing special. Those who held out on their upgrades will upgrade, but it makes no sense for those with an iPhone 4/4s to upgrade. The benefit is minuscule. Apple is going to have a good Q4 with everybody in a similar position to me upgrading, but iPhone 5 will not take away market-share from Samsung and it seems to me like apple is getting close to the ceiling on iPhone sales. Stock still has some upside on Q4 results, but the top is closer than ever before.

Topic.Title: 27% of Anroid users decide I-5 is better.....

Message.Msg: screen is out of wack you say..... funny you should say that..... Monday, September 24, 2012, 20:49 pm iPhone 5 outperforms Samsung's Galaxy S III in display test By Mikey Campbell A comprehensive side-by-side examination of the Apple and Samsung flagship smartphones was performed by display testing firm DisplayMate Technologies, which found the iPhone 5's 4-inch Retina display to be more refined than the OLED unit found in the Galaxy S III. DisplayMate's "Flagship Smartphone Display Technology Shoot-Out" not only pitted the iPhone 5 against the Galaxy S III, but added in the iPhone 4's Retina display to show how Apple's display technology has advanced over the past two years. The test consisted of numerous tests covering screen reflections, brightness and contrast, colors and intensities, viewing angles, display power consumption and effect on battery life. "Apple has uncharacteristically understated how much better the display is on the iPhone 5 – something that could be an important factor for those considering whether to upgrade," said DisplayMate's Dr. Raymond Soneira. "In every category that we measure (except Brightness Decrease with Viewing Angle), the performance of the iPhone 5 display has improved over the iPhone 4, sometimes by a bit and sometimes by a lot." Compared to the iPhone 4, the iPhone 5 has decreased screen reflectance by 52 percent, boosted contrast by 57 percent and improved color accuracy. Soneira notes the iPhone 5's display calibration is very good and, while suffering from minor gamma intensity, that "It is still probably more accurate than any display you own, unless you have a new iPad. […] it is the Brightest Smartphone we have tested in the Shoot-Out series, it has one of the lowest screen Reflectance values we have ever measured, it has the highest Contrast Rating for High Ambient Light for any Mobile device we have ever tested, and it’s Color Gamut and Factory Calibration are second only to the new iPad. What are the downsides? The White Point is still somewhat too blue like most Smartphones, and at Maximum Brightness it has a shorter Running Time than the iPhone 4, which is not surprising since it has a larger screen and a larger Color Gamut but roughly the same capacity battery. As for Samsung's Galaxy S III, the device's PenTile display performed admirably, but the OLED technology the screen leverages is still being perfected and is not up to par with the LCD tech used in the iPhone 5. Highlights from the Galaxy S III test: The Brightness is about half of the iPhone 5 due to power limits from the lower power efficiency of OLEDs and concerns regarding premature OLED aging. The Color Gamut is not only much larger than the Standard Color Gamut, which leads to distorted and exaggerated colors, but the Color Gamut is quite lopsided, with Green being a lot more saturated than Red or Blue, which adds a Green color caste to many images. Samsung has not bothered to correct or calibrate their display colors to bring them into closer agreement with the Standard sRGB / Rec.709 Color Gamut, so many images appear over saturated and gaudy. Running Time on battery is less than the iPhone 5 due to the lower power efficiency of OLEDs, even given that the Galaxy S III has a much larger battery capacity and much lower Brightness. Overall, the iPhone 5 scored an "A" rating while the Galaxy S III earned a "B+" on poor calibration and viewing angle issues.

(NASDAQ:AAPL): Jefferies stated that its channel checks suggest the addition of Sony (NYSE:SNE) to the list of in-cell display suppliers to the iPhone 5 has resolved what was the main supply bottleneck. Jefferies maintains a Buy rating and a $900 price target on the stock.

He says he's not a flip-flopper. Yet…plenty of Republican voters don't seem to believe him. They have plenty of reasons not to. As Romney has moved from Massachusetts politics to GOP presidential politics, he has famously reversed course on abortion rights, gun control, gay rights, and health care reform. And it's all on video. Still, Romney keeps on denying any somersaults, but not convincingly. Now there's new video out showing that Romnney has indeed pulled a 180 on his entire political persona. And it's in Romney's own words. In 2002, when he was running for governor in Massachusetts, he issued a strong declaration of his basic principles while campaigning in Worcester: I think the old standby definitions of who votes for which party have been blown away in this campaign. I think people recognize that I'm not a partisan Republican—that I'm someone who is moderate, and that my views are progressive. Here's the worth-more-than-a-1,000-words clip: Google: Mitt Romney in Worcester 2002 "My views are progressive" A moderate, progressive, and nonpartisan Republican—that's how Romney described himself just five years before first running for the Republican presidential nomination as a fierce conservative. In his 2010 book, No Apology: The Case for American Greatness, Romney huffed, "progressives…rejected the notion of universal truths, objective judgments, and, ironically, progress itself, embracing neutrality among competing belief sets and rejecting the primacy of Western civilization, the great thinkers of the ages, and the principles espoused by the Founding Parents of the nation." Yet Romney once proudly declared himself a fellow of progressive views. Maybe he should apologize.] ======== [Romney said about John Carry: "This nation can't afford [presidential leadership] that comes in 57 varieties." Yet he flip-flops anytime to get the votes he needs.] ======== [1994 United States Senate campaign I believe that abortion should be safe and legal in this country. I have since the time that my Mom took that position when she ran in 1970 as a U.S. Senate candidate. I believe that since Roe v. Wade has been the law for 20 years we should sustain and support it. Look, I was an independent during the time of Reagan-Bush. I'm not trying to take us back to Reagan-Bush. As a result of [my campaign's] discussions and other interactions with gay and lesbian voters across the state, I am more convinced than ever that as we seek to establish full equality for America's gay and lesbian citizens, I will provide more effective leadership than Ted Kennedy.] ========= [2003-2007 Governor of Massachusetts The definition of marriage is so fundamental to society that it should not be decided by one court in [Massachusetts] or by one mayor in San Francisco. In [America], the people should decide. In America, the people are fair and tolerant. Let the people decide.] ========= Go ahead, vote for "you never know which Mitt gonna show up" for work!

Topic.Title: How stupid is AAPL?

Message.Msg: Two of your listed items make no sense, because YouTube and Google search are not gone. The third is just the crisis-du-jour for Apple critics. (1) YouTube is still available on the iPhone in the very same way that it is available on billions of computers worldwide: through the browser. The only thing that changed is the dedicated app for that has been removed. No big deal. Ninety nine percent of the time that I ended up viewing a YouTube hosted video on my iPhone was due to clicking on something in the browser. (2) The default search engine in the browser on the iPhone is still Google,same as it ever was. If I instead ask Siri for something that she can't resolve otherwise, she also directs the search to Google. This has not changed, so what's your beef? (3) This whole mapgate thing is a tempest in a teapot. The new Apple map app has improved my quality of life immeasurably. The turn-by-turn instructions are fantastic (something that Google refused to supply iPhone users in their map service) and I have yet to encounter the "disastrous" issues with bad data in my neck of the woods. With over a hundred million users of iOS 6 already, each of them trying out the new features, I am not surprised that some small fraction of issues have been uncovered, especially given the scrutiny that any Apple offering (hardware or software) receives. Google maps have issues too, I have discovered over the years, but nobody seems to write or care about those. One year from now, everyone will forget about this hoopla. Thompson

Message.Title: Current product review from an Apple junky
Message.Msg: I have been long on apple since the Wintel switch. I have also spent 10k on apple products in the past 10 years. iPhone 5 - just got it today via UPS. It feels like a marginal upgrade, and I upgraded from the iPhone 4. Apple places as much if not more of their R&D focus on hardware as software. This phone just is not making me want to buy more stock. Macbook Retina - The best laptop I have ever owned. I have owned this for a month now. Everything is snappy due to the SSD. Screen is unbelievable. However, my 17 inch macbook pro was almost as good and I don't know anyone except me that is lining up to spend 2k on a laptop. I am not buying AAPL because of this laptop. iCloud - Almost as frustrating as MobileMe. Using multiple devices and having what you want where you want it is a complete fail. Not buying AAPL for iCloud. iPad 3 - I used it and returned it. My iPad 2 and iPad 1 work just fine. Not buying AAPL for iPad 3 either. iTunes 10 - Apple has refused to roll in more advanced features into iTunes. Searching and finding anything is an effort in Stupid. Not buying AAPL for iTunes 10. Bottom line, I liquidated at $704. I am going to sit on the sidelines for a while until Apple shows it has its vision and direction back. My feeling about Apple right now is about the same as I felt in the 90's, languishing and resting, out of fresh ideas, and too worried about making a mistake. They need to be trying something new every six months. Technology leaders take chances, Apple right now is taking none. The iPhone 5 is the perfect example, unless you are a freak for lighter weight, nothing is interesting about this phone.

Message.Title: Sold my Apple stock to buy Nokia
Message.Msg: Nokia has: 1) A lot of great partnerships (MSFT, Ford etc.) 2) A great phone brand with the Lumia 820 & 920 that's the best on the market. 3) Nokia Navigation/Maps is the best on the market and can be licensed out. 4) Nokia Life & Lite+ which is Nokias own search engine. 5) Nokia Music 6) They have an endless supply of innovative patents. 7) They still might release a tablet which will give them another product on the market. At Nokia's current pps of $2.70, with only 3.7 billion shares on the market, and a market cap of only 10 billion, this time next year Nokia can be trading around $21+; to do so they only need a market of about 70 Billion. With everything Nokia has going on you have to be crazy to think a 70 Billion dollar market cap is impossible, I believe it's still extremely modest. Apple had its day, now it's Nokia's time again ----- NOK Nokia is a STRONG BUY & HOLD!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

In China- The weekend violence is the latest in a growing list of incidents that have heightened concerns over conditions in factories that make iPhones and other high-volume tech products. There have been employee suicides, explosions at two plants that make Apple gadgets, and reports of harsh working conditions. A New York Times investigation of the manufacturing of Apple products in China in January painted a picture of a company that wants to improve the workplace at its partners such as Foxconn but "falters when it conflicts with crucial supplier relationships or the fast delivery of new products."

Message.Title: Calm down! Look at the facts and do the math...
Message.Msg: Let's look at what we know: 1. Sold more than 5 million units over the weekend. 2. 2 millions iPhone pre-ordered. Probably 1.5 millions units will be shipped and received and be counted toward this quarter's sales. 3. 3 to 5 millions will likely be on the way or already in the stores/channels for the countries that will be selling the iPhone 5 starting this Friday. 4. There will likely be more than 1 million units currently still available for sale in the stores/channels in the USA. 5. Apple will likely be selling more than 1 million iPhone 5 for this week to be counted toward this quarter. Do the math, conservatively: Apple will likely be able to include 7 to 8 millions units of iPhone 5 for this quarter. For those that complained about mis-managed supply chain, I have the following to say: 1. Hindsighted is so easy. NO ONE know for sure in advance if any product will be selling good, so so or poorly. 2. The majority of the componets probably had been ordered more than 3 months in advance but the final engineering design probably was not signed off until a couple of months ago. That would leave about one month for the production people to prepare the product for manufacturing, setting up test equipments and procure the last minute items, work out the logistics, etc. 3. This left about one month for the actual manufacturing to start, tweak the process, ramp up the production, store and ship the items to the warehouses and stores. 4. If we add up the numbers, Apple suppliers have to manufacture/provide more than 10 millions units of a new product in less than one month including shipping time. This is just amazing! Stay calm and be real!

Topic.Title: Go Try A Samsung Before You Invest in Apple

Message.Msg: I own an iPhone 4 (not 4S) and a Samsung Galaxy S3. S3 is a solid phone. Best android yet BUT the iphone 4 is better if somebody made me choose just one. iPhone is just more elegant, slicker, easier to use, more intuitive, nicer looking and more ergonomic. I bought an S3 just to see what all the hype was about and have had it for well over a month now and take it with me everyday along with the iphone. It does a few things better than iPhone if you are a big user of the google ecosystem (gmail, picasa, calendar) but iphone does these things too but just not as well as some native google apps. I don't even have the new iPhone 5 yet so can only imagine how much better that is than the S3 if my 4 is already better.

Message.Title: Shorted 0.127 shared today for someone elses account! yippee...
Message.Msg: 90% of you people really are nutters. This company seems not much more than a marketing magician with mediocre technology and drug-addicted customers. Having owned the 4s since November, the only nice thing I can say about it is: when it works, its great... but the other 85% of the time I feel like smashing it, but since my wife got us stuck on a stinkin Verizon two year contract the only thing I can do is vent on this crumby board. Here's a Siri classic: "Where is Washington St in Brookline, Massachusetts?" First answer: some random st in Washington, DC. Second answer, Washington St in some random town in Indiana. Third answer, Washington St in the capitol of Idaho! How about 32gb of memory which makes no difference in terms of performance? The OS sucks and memory leaks are rampant. Trivially simple applications that run like snails abound. Any machine language program from 20 years ago runs better! That #$%$ PC-laptop of mine? Don't need to reboot that much more than once a week... the #$%$ 4s? Everyday... Perhaps when China shuts down all manufacturers of Apple products, this stock will reflect its true value. Talk about corporate social irresponsibility, this company takes top honors for ignoring their responsibilities to the world. Until recently, their annual corporate social responsibility report did not even name Foxconn as their number one supplier. Also, doesn't all that cash reflect a failure in corporate governance of moronic proportions? If they don't know what to do with it, give it back to the shareholders!

Message.Msg: Apple is selling their LATEST & BEST iPhone 5 that is NOT the latest and best technology offered by competition. What the rat's fart were they thinking??? Message.Title: The FACT that all the dumb analysts are forgetting.
Message.Msg: AAPL stocked its stores with more product and retailers with less. They did this as a startegy to control the sales process better and upsell more add-ons. They also book the sale immediately so they will be able to boost this quarter's sales. The retailers push whatever product they like with little loyality to AAPL. Computer Manufacturers i.e. IBM, HP and Dell have been doing this for years. AAPL is just following suit. The numbers will be a big beat this quarter. Mark my words. I deal with AAPL Execs on a regular basis in my profession.

Topic.Title: The FACT that all the dumb analysts are forgetting.

Message.Msg: Not sure I understand your question. What I am saying is that AAPL as well as all hardware companies book a sale when it is in the hands of the customer. With a store, you walk out with a phone. When its mailed to you the sale is booked when it reaches the customers hand. Sign for it or delivered to their doorstep. Sales are not booked just because an order was placed or the product is in transit. UPS may lose it for example.

Message.Title: Analysts increased target price to 770, at FPE of 12 good entry point
Message.Msg: AAPL sold on news - current FPE of 12 (compared with 15 for GOOG) and analysts target increased to $770, makes the current 670 as a good entry point. Coming weekly iPhone 5 numbers would be good, announcement about iPad Mini any day (before shopping season begins), and a deal with China Mobile any day all point to positive catalysts that should propel stock to $770. AAPL Map issue has been overblown, subsequent software upgrade will fix the problems and within a short period AAPL Maps would be fine (it's not a hardware proble; software problems are easier to fix). It would have been certainly better if AAPL Maps would be perfect the first time. AAPL got hurt because of the Foxconn news - but it has been resolved and production is back on track. AAPL numbers of 5 mi phones over weekend is a record for any phone and judging from long lines in every major city around where it has been offered, one cannot be too disappointed in the numbers. Before earnings, you will hear numbers looking better and better. AAPL will increase outlook for 4Q12. Overall, given such a low PE for a growth tech company, it's hard to paint a bearish picture for AAPL. Buy now!

Message.Title: When will Google upgrade to vector based maps?
Message.Msg: Most of the people( including Cramer) that talk about the Apple maps don't realize it is better technology then Google's bandwidth hogging multi-resolution image based technology. Any errors which I have not seen will become less and less within days. These are type of errors where you fix one and fixes hundreds at a time as the alignment is fine tuned. For me, the app is better because of the turn by turn feature which Google failed to offer to the iPhone. It is flawless so far. There will be many nice features that Apple will be able to exploit with vector based technology that will ultimately put pressure on Google to upgrade. The 3d seems to be for fun but the implementation is very nicely done. Go check out Rome. Rotate the Coliseum and check it out from all angles. I am sure this will be integrated further. Google has no answer for this feature. Google does have street view which is nice but I will take the turn by turn feature over street view anytime. Vectors are better!

Message.Title: The Apple brand name has been damaged. Time to sell.
Message.Msg: Probably everyone who wants a new Iphone has one, meanwhile it appears RIMM may offer a viable alternative in January. So far reviews are promising. Now, I love Apple and Amazon, but the issues with Chinese labor and Apple will hurt profits. Amazon is overvalued, RIMM is worth the risk, but I really really like Bed Bath and Beyond who guided conservatively. Having split my living time in two different under performing Republican states, I can say that the parking lots at BBBY are filling up finally. The CEO failed to mention traffic was improving perhaps because it was outside of the quarter just reported. But consider this: Not only are more people shopping, Amazon starts charging sales tax in a few days which will drive more traffic to BBBY. I haven't spent one unnecessary dime for two years, so I have a lot of catching up to prepare for the holidays. I am also a very hands on shopper like most women and I don't mind paying extra because it's not that much. Really.

Topic.Title: The Apple brand name has been damaged. Time to sell.

Message.Msg: I guess if RIMM uses Asian Manufacturersm their brand name is OK. Get outta here... According to this 2009 Bloomberg article, RIM’s five biggest suppliers account for 90% of its production costs. They are: Elcoteq SE: Elcoteq is a Finnish company with a global factory network that includes “a regional office in Hong Kong, branch office of Beijing in Shenzhen, an Engineering Service Center and after-market services unit in Beijing and high-volume manufacturing units in Beijing and Dongguan.” Jabil Circuit, Inc.: Jabil is a successful U.S. multinational company whose customers include Apple, Cisco, GE, IBM, and Research In Motion. Much of its manufacturing is done in Asia. “Prior to 2005, it acquired a Lucent Technologies plant in Shanghai, China. The company later added the electronics manufacturing business of Varian Inc. to its arsenal. It opened new facilities in China, India, and Ukraine, and expanded plants in Hungary, Malaysia, Mexico, and the United States. During 2006, Jabil set its sights on Taiwan Green Point Enterprises Co., a manufacturer of plastic casings used for items including cell phones, iPods, and Blackberry devices.” Multi-Fineline Electronix Inc.: A U.S. company who makes RIM’s flexible circuit boards at its manufacturing facilities in Suzhou, China. QUALCOMM is another important supplier who’s CDMA development center is in Beijing although it’s not clear which of its many overseas facilities supplies RIM. In all fairness, it’s becoming extremely difficult for any company to not set up manufacturing facilities in China if it wants to stay competitive and, most likely, all mobile phone providers have the same issue as RIM. The difference is that only RIM is selling a claim of secure communications without addressing how they are securing their supply chain. And until they do that, RIM’s enterprise customers should not place their trust solely in RIM’s BES encryption benefit.

Topic.Title: Cheaper to make iPhone 5

Message.Msg: Figures should include the cost of maybe 2 million Iphones being returned and damaged goods. A worker at Foxconn said only 10 out of 100 were good phones. Lets wait and see who is telling the truth. I have worked for very large companies at a high level and knowing how the end of each quarter works for added revenue. I have seen first hand, orders filled with only parts of an order or send anything in stock and wait for the customer to send them back. We have sent out 10 tractor trailers filled with product on the last day of the quarter, 3 weeks after the quarter we had 5 tractor trailers come back filled with returned goods. It is all about the numbers with big companies. If I had the time I could show how a large company can show growth for 5 years without any real growth. No audit will catch a very large corporation doing anything wrong if you know how it is done. I am not talking about Apple, I deal with companies that manufacture their own products... Apple could fudge sales numbers like last year Cook said they sold 45 Million Iphones in one quarter and months later we found that number was only 38 Million.. Last quarter was bad for Apple, This quarter will be bad for Apple. There is no way Apple will meet or beat Analysts numbers this quarter.

Message.Msg: apple has always been so far ahead of the pack that holding this stock was a no brainer. the iphone 5 is not enough to separate apple from the competition. it was such a disappointment that many people, including myself, are actually going to question whether the iphone5 is the best phone out there and many will decide in the negative. android, especially samsung, is innovating very quickly. making matters worse, tim cook has not shown the same love of quality that steve jobs did. siri, the voice recognition utility, is so pitiful that it borders on comedy. and from what i've heard, not seen, the news maps app is subpar. this also puts apple squarely in the "just another tech option" camp and that IS NOT how apple become the largest company in the world. blazing spot on innovation and very high quality is what got them there. both of those characters appear to be gone in 1 short year. why is it such a problem. well, apple gets by far the lionshare of profits from the iPhone! yes, believe. all the movies, music, macs, routers, iPods, iPads, etc., each provide a small part of their profit! Topic.Title: its all very simple

Message.Msg: i'm sure they'll sell plenty, but it won't change my opinion. i think that the luster is gone. the iphone 5 is just wrong. too tall, too light, and lots of "eh". the iPhone 4 was not wide enough as it was, and the iphone 5 makes it even worse. is it me, or is it downright painful to even look at that long screen. and i am a BIG apple fan. but i'm an objective type also. the phone should have been wider, not taller, and much heavier. did they think steve jobs made the 4s so heavy because he couldn't find lighter parts? does cook think siri is a fun app, like a joke, not really meant to be used to utilize apps like calendaring, and getting information from the internet? i've tried using siri at least 5 times because i truly wanted to use it and each time i was dumbstruck at how unsable it is. do you know anyone that uses it? i don't. i'm very disappointment. i sold first thing monday morning after making my decision over the weekend. i'm glad i did. but apple was 80% of my portfolio and i planned on holding it for a much longer time. i know that macs will crush msft, but i cannot hold the stock when 80% of its profit comes from one product and that product has lost all the advantage that it had and has officially become just another product of its kind. heck, you can actually make an argument that it is an inferior phone at this point. at the very least, its a discussion. prior to the iPhone 5, there was NO DISCUSSION as to what was the best phone. by a mile.

Again, you have to ask this simple question. For the rest of AAPL II life, can it make additional 600B... If your answer is yes, go ahead and hold on to your dear life. If the answer is NO, well... Enjoy the angry bird moments.

Topic.Title: its all very simple

Message.Msg: Um, Walt Mossberg says that the iphone 5 is the best smartphone on the market. It is actually much better in comparison to the competition than all the previous generations of iphone. And, the previous generations have fared quite well. So things look quite promising for AAPl. They didn't make it wider because it cant be used with one hand if they made it wider like the clunky galaxy III. Do you really think AAPL could win the size contest if they wanted to? The width restriction was voluntary, and it was smart. They will sell 50mm iphones before the end of the year and over 200mm iphone 5's in the next year. Sell AAPL at your peril.

Topic.Title: its all very simple

Message.Msg: I agree with the disappointing screen size......and for all the hype, the phone doesn't really "deliver" anything, nor is it innovative. Will they sell a lot of them, for sure...but I don't think it's the best phone out there....the Galaxy III is pretty sweet
